body: Would like to see how flaky this `test_on_kill` actually is.
@feluelle I think that extending sleep time in this test seems to work. It's a test that runs a DAG and terminates it, imho there's no guarantee that everything will be done in 3s.

@potiuk Thanks for your advices, actually I try to understand how Airflow Breeze work during those days.

pre-commit configure work with 

```sh
      - id: setup-order
        name: Checks for an order of dependencies in setup.py
        language: system
        files: ^setup.py$
        pass_filenames: false
        require_serial: true
        entry: "python ./tests/test_order_setup.py"
```

Will create a new commit tomorrow

You can also run chmod +x ./tests/test_order_setup.py and add shebang "#!/usr/bin/env python" at the beginning of the file to make it executable and get it back to 'entry: tests/test_order_setup.py'

@zhongjiajie -> good that you want to learn how breeze works :). BTW. make sure to take a look at the latest updates to the docs done with Technical Writer Elena: https://github.com/PolideaInternal/airflow/blob/more-gsod-improvements/CONTRIBUTING.rst
working on it
@ultrabug Apologies this had to wait for this long. Let's make this happen this time for sure.
Can you also please rebase against current master, please?

> The sasl lib (https://github.com/cloudera/python-sasl/tree/master/sasl) is a wrapper around the Cyrus SASL library, that should support it, but sadly I wasn't able to make it work with Kerberos (so I was blocked one step before the current issue). There is a pull request to refresh the bindings (cloudera/python-sasl#15), but nobody from upstream is paying attention

@elukey 

I am author of cloudera/python-sasl#15 - closed that PR as Cloudera didn't pay attention to recent pull requests 
I've published sasl3 package on pypi
https://pypi.org/project/sasl3/
https://github.com/sparkur/python-sasl3

Please give that a try instead if `sasl` 

Thank you
I added this PR to the queue next week. I will try to review it as soon as possible.
@potiuk This PR is ready for review, PTAL
Cool! very nice. Thanks @zhongjiajie !
I also cherry-picked it to v1-10-test :)

While working on adding more type annotations I've found more cyclic dependencies in Plugins manager. I managed to untangle them in this commit as a follow-up after the "executors" untangling.

As result - we have much smaller airflow.__init__.py, and the dependencies are much more straightforward and not cyclic:

```
airflow -> PluginsManager -> [operators/hooks/macros/sensors] 
```

rather than

```
airflow -> [operators/hooks/macros/sensors]  -> PluginsManager -> [operators/hooks/macros/sensors] 
```

I also made most of the affected files pylint + mypy compliant.

Last time I looked at this PR (Sorry, it slipped off my radar!) it was making an distinction between "the next execution date is X" and "the DAG is currently at it's max runs, so I'll show None" -- which I feel is _more_ confusing than helpful, as the next execution date would "magically" go from None to a date based on how many the active runs which doesn't feel like a helpful message.

We've already got a (bad) way of showing in the UI that a dag is at it's max runs, so lets not have a second one.

> It also seems that about 2/3 of the files have change s unrelated to removing cyclic imports!
> 
> I am a strong beliver in having a useful git history with commit messages, especially for changes that are large, so having ~60 files with change associated with a commit that says "avoid cyclic imports" when the change is unrelated to that makes me less than happy.
> 
> Please could we split all the unrelated change out (mostly all the `# pylint:x` to `pylint: x` comments). Is the first wrong, or are we just favouring one over the other? If so we should also add a lint rule to enforce this style.

Sure. Some of the changes were just really helpful with untangling the dependencies (but specifically the "pylint" ones was a byproduct). But now it should be easy to separate out some of those changes into separate commits. I will do it shortly.

> > Please could we split all the unrelated change out (mostly all the `# pylint:x` to `pylint: x` comments). Is the first wrong, or are we just favouring one over the other? If so we should also add a lint rule to enforce this style.
> 
> Sure. Some of the changes were just really helpful with untangling the dependencies (but specifically the "pylint" ones was a byproduct). But now it should be easy to separate out some of those changes into separate commits. I will do it shortly.

Thank you very much - I ask because I've used `git bisect` a couple of times over the last few weeks on Airflow to track down bugs already :)

> Is this going to make it slower -- i.e. does this genrate a list of keys and then do a list search for the key vs just a direct hash lookup?
> 
> What was the error? This feels like a bug in mypy rather than a bug in our code.

That used to be much slower in python2, but in python3 it's just a bit slower as keys() does not return list of keys (as it used to be) but DictKeyView() (which is backed by the original dict and is updated as the dict updates). See for example here (I repeated those benchmarks with similar results): https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10205969/why-in-operator-with-tuple-as-a-key-in-python-so-slow. And the overhead is not proportional to the size of the dict - it's more to construct the dynamic ListView. And "in" operator is equally fast - doint hash lookup() rather than linear search as it used to be in Python2.

This change was more of my process of adding types - I wanted to understand all the types and make sure they are correct, so I can revert it.

> Thank you very much - I ask because I've used git bisect a couple of times over the last few weeks on Airflow to track down bugs already :)

@potiuk We once talked that DAG serialization can be done by serializing class arguments in the database. This PR brings us closer to implementing this idea.

> @potiuk We once talked that DAG serialization can be done by serializing class arguments in the database. This PR brings us closer to implementing this idea.

We discussed this initially, however that can easily become a pain as the Serialized Blob grows in sizes rapidly. We don't need all the information (of a task) for the Webserver and the Scheduler. Hence, the 1st task of DAG Serialization was to figure out what information is actually required by the Webserver.

Increased JSON Blob size caused performance issues when we benchmarked it in #5743 so we reduced the blob size to as small as we could.

What do you think to save the generated links in a separate column in the database after Task execution?  I think it will be nicer because it will not be storing additional partial data, but the final data that interests us.  This could be realized independent of DAG serialization. In addition, it will simplify the logic of handling these links. Now it is not possible to download all links for a given task, but we download one link in one HTTP request. https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/master/airflow/www/templates/airflow/dag.html#L492-L518
I would love to wait for Jarek's changes. I am pleased with the warm words about this change.
